items.title: Formencode Email validator does not recognize emails with name
items.body:
Lots of email programs use the format

    "User Name <user@email.com>"

formencode.validators.Email fails to validate this format.

```
>>> Email.to_python("asdf@asdf.asdf")
'asdf@asdf.asdf'
>>> Email.to_python("My Name <asdf@asdf.asdf>")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/vagrant/bigleaf/lib/python3.4/site-packages/formencode/api.py", line 479, in to_python
    vp(value, state)
  File "/home/vagrant/bigleaf/lib/python3.4/site-packages/formencode/validators.py", line 1354, in _validate_python
    value, state)
formencode.api.Invalid: The username portion of the email address is invalid (the portion before the @: My Name <asdf)
```

items.title: 1.3.0 cannot provide a universal wheel
items.body:
When FormEncode is installed with semi-modern versions of pip, pip will first build a wheel and then cache it. Because the project has [`universal = 1` in the wheel section of your setup.cfg](https://github.com/formencode/formencode/blob/1.3.0/setup.cfg#L29), pip will cache the wheel and indicate that the built wheel is suitable for py2 and py3. The problem is that the project uses 2to3 to ensure that FormEncode is correct for the version of Python it installs on. So if you run your tests against Python 2 first, then FormEncode will fail on Python 3.

Could a patch version of 1.3.0 be released with `universal = 0`? This means pip will cache two separate wheels, one for py2 and one for py3.

items.title: `variable_decode` behaves differently in Py2 vs. Py3
items.body:
thanks for the great package!

i found a slight API inconsistency between python 2 to 3. in py2:

``` python
>>> import formencode.variabledecode
>>> aa = {'liige-1.name': 'name', 'liige.0.country': 'EE', 'liige-0.name': ''}
>>> formencode.variabledecode.variable_decode(aa)
{'liige': [{'name': ''}, {'name': 'name'}, {'country': 'EE'}]}
```

but py3 throws an exception:

``` python
>>> import formencode.variabledecode
>>> aa = {'liige-1.name': 'name', 'liige.0.country': 'EE', 'liige-0.name': ''}
>>> formencode.variabledecode.variable_decode(aa)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "formencode/variabledecode.py", line 101, in variable_decode
    to_sort = [x[1] for x in sorted(to_sort)]
TypeError: unorderable types: str() < int()
```

the "right" way to fix this would be to throw an "invalid key name" exception for "liige.0.country" since it should be "liige-0.country", which would change py2 behaviour.

however, to maintain current py2 functionality, formencode/variabledecode.py:101 could be changed to:

``` python
to_sort = [x[1] for x in sorted(to_sort, key=repr)]
```

or something similar that would allow `sorted` to handle any key type.

items.title: tests appear to be broken, or at least undocumented.
items.body:
The tests appear to be broken.  This might be covered by some ToDo.txt items, I'm not sure.

• a first selection of unittest tests are runnable via `python setup.py test`.  all pass.
• a second selection of nosetest tests (for the validators?) seem to be available from the file `run-tests-generate-coverage-html`.  many seem to be out of data with current function names and fail.
• a third selection of tests don't seem to be called from anything, notably the `test_htmlfill.py` file.

items.title: Feature Request - ability to disable htmlfill for tags
items.body:
Using htmlfill on form errors is great, but it can be rather limiting in that it can only handle a single form on a given page by default.  If there are multiple forms on a page (such as login & register), all elements on both forms are processed with the defaults from the error.  The only existing workaround for this is to generate forms separately, and then pipe them into a template as partials.  Depending on an applications workflow, this might not be easily accomplished.  we found it's much easier to just put prefixes on all the "logical" forms, so there is no overlap.  It's an annoying apporach though.

A novel approach that looks like it might work, would be to use tag attributes to control how htmlfill works with more granularity.

• render a tag with a prefix to disable formencode from rewriting that tag:

```
<input type="text" name="foo" value="bar" data-htmlfill-ignore="true" />
<input type="text" name="foo" value="bar" data-formencode-ignore="1" />
<input type="text" name="foo" value="bar" data-formencode="ignore" />
```

• render a tag with an attribute that declares a form "set", used  to group forms together.  if a "form_set" or "form_name" is passed into `htmlfill.render`, only form elements with a matching tag will be rendered

```
<input type="text" name="foo" value="bar" data-formencode-form="form_a" />
<input type="text" name="foo" value="bar" data-formencode-set="form_a" />
```

items.title: Int().to_python(None) get None
items.body:
``` python
#coding:utf-8
from formencode import validators

print validators.Int().to_python(None)
```

get None, however _to_python works right, but when in Schema, How to do that?

items.title: `TypeError` when using numeric arguments with `htmlfill_schemabuilder`
items.body:
Could be that I don't quite understand how to pass arguments in the markup since the documentation on that is rather scarce, but here's the markup I tried to use:

```
<input type="text" name="foo" form:validate="minlength:4">
```

The argument safely makes it all the way to the correct validator, but as `unicode` object rather than a number resulting in a `TypeError` exception. Here's the original traceback of the TypeError caught by the validator:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "vendor\formencode\validators.py", line 414, in _validate_python
    minLength=self.minLength), value, state)
  File "vendor\formencode\api.py", line 262, in message
    return msg % kw
TypeError: %d format: a number is required, not unicode
```

I'm currently 'fixing' this by using coercion:

```
    def _validate_python(self, value, state):
        self.minLength = int(self.minLength)
        ....
```

Of course, this isn't a good solution. It would be better to fix this in `htmlfill_schemabuilder`  somewhere, but I wasn't sure how to address it.

items.title: Add a test for variable decode where there are two adjacent dashes
items.body: The condition was fixed in #55 but we should have a test.

items.title: Schema fields aren't copied on instance __call__
items.body:
If `foo` is an instance of a `Schema`, then according to the docs `foo(**kw)` should copy `foo` without modifying it. However, if you pass in sub-validators, they do modify it:

``` python
>>> from formencode import Schema
>>> # An empty schema
>>> class Foo(Schema): pass
...
>>> # Convert to an instance
>>> Foo = Foo()
>>> # The instance is boring
>>> print Foo
<Foo object 54 chained_validators=[] fields={} pre_validators=[]>
>>> # Calling it creates a copy
>>> print Foo(x=12)
<Foo object 54 chained_validators=[] fields={} pre_validators=[] x=12>
>>> # The original is unchanged
>>> print Foo
<Foo object 54 chained_validators=[] fields={} pre_validators=[]>
>>> # Calling it creates a copy
>>> print Foo(x=Foo())
<Foo object 54 chained_validators=[] fields={'x': <Foo object 54 chained_validators=[] fields={...} pre_validators=[]>} pre_validators=[]>
>>> # But now the original is changed, too!
>>> print Foo
<Foo object 54 chained_validators=[] fields={'x': <Foo object 54 chained_validators=[] fields={...} pre_validators=[]>} pre_validators=[]>
```

Either this shouldn't happen, or the docs should be updated to explain why this happens.

Thanks!
Dan L

items.title: Number validator should trap TypeError
items.body:
The Number validator doesn't trap the TypeError exception while trying to convert its value to float. This results in certain values (esp. lists) throwing a TypeError instead of the expected invalid:

```
In [8]: from formencode import validators
In [9]: validators.Number().to_python([1,2])
...
TypeError: float() argument must be a string or a number
```

This is not the case for other validators, e.g., Int:

```
In [10]: validators.Int().to_python([1,2])
...
Invalid: Please enter an integer value
```

items.title: Postal Code Format validator not translating (v1.2.6 and branch master)
Documentation needs updates for Custom Validator examples
items.body:
Hello,

3 methods showed in the "Writing Your Own Validator" of the documentation section no longer exists or have been renamed since.

So if you follow the documentation, the validate functiosn will never be called.

_validate_others has been renamed to validate_others.
_convert_to_python has been renamed to _to_python.
_validate_python has been renamed to _validate_python

Regards

items.title: String length validation confusing error message
items.body:
The tooLong message is now: "Enter a value less than %(maxLength)i characters long"

It should really be "Enter a value less than or equal to %(maxLength)i characters long"

(The check is `len(value) > self.max)`).

I am using python-formencode-1.2.2-7.

items.title: validators.DateConverter doesn't accept RFC 3339-style dates
items.body:
Hi. As far as I can tell, at the moment the codebase doesn't support converting a [RFC 3339](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6) date in the style "yyyy-mm-dd". This is a very unconventional way for humans to write a date, but it is probably going to become important because it's the only format returned by the [HTML5 date input field](http://dev.w3.org/html5/markup/input.date.html) (and it won't send anything else to a server without javascript hackery). There isn't wide support for this yet but Chrome and the stock Android browser (at least) do both support it, and it's something I'm using in a project and so missing it in formencode.

Please do correct me if I'm wrong about either formencode not supporting it or it being the only format returned by the date field! Otherwise, is there interest in a patch that can support this style?

items.title: validators.Email validator does not accept a valid email address
items.body:
one of our cosumers wrote us:

> This contact form rejects valid e-mail addresses which contain a plus (+) sign.

items.title: validators.PhoneNumber validator does not accept a valid phone number
items.body:
Hello, one of our (bills4btc.com) users has problems with the validation of a Finish phone number:

> I can't enter international phone numbers, because the form insists on a ###-###-#### format. For example in my case, my Finnish phone number is +XXX-XX-XXXXXXX and the biller's number is +XXX-XX-XXXXXX ([...]). Both of those numbers caused an error to be displayed.

items.title: Validator.accept_iterator should default to True
items.body:
Hi! This is a big API-breaking change, and it's not stated docs how to turn this on -  I had to grep the source code: 

https://readthedocs.org/search/project/?q=accept_iterator&selected_facets=project_exact%3AFormEncode), 

I'd have expected that this sort of thing would default therefore to accept_iterator=True, so we don't have to run around turning it on in all our classes that have any sort of nested object structure which FormEncode was designed to support. 

Thanks!

items.title: Can't (automatically) copy a CompountValidator
items.body:
According to https://github.com/formencode/formencode/blob/master/formencode/declarative.py#L153, one can copy a validator by calling it again. This is handy, since validators' `.to_python()` method can be called from a class or an instance, but other methods require an instance (like `.is_empty()`). So, we can be sure that doing `my_validator().my_method()` results in the right thing done.

Except that `CompoundValidator` can't be copied this way:

``` python
>>> from formencode import FancyValidator
>>> from formencode.compound import CompoundValidator
>>> FancyValidator()()
<FancyValidator object 54>
>>> c = CompoundValidator()
>>> c()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/jon/.../eggs/FormEncode-1.2.4-py2.7.egg/formencode/declarative.py", line 158, in __call__
    return self.__class__(*args, **current)
  File "/home/jon/.../eggs/FormEncode-1.2.4-py2.7.egg/formencode/compound.py", line 45, in __init__
    Validator.__init__(self, *args, **kw)
  File "/home/jon/.../eggs/FormEncode-1.2.4-py2.7.egg/formencode/api.py", line 209, in __init__
    declarative.Declarative.__init__(self, *args, **kw)
  File "/home/jon/.../eggs/FormEncode-1.2.4-py2.7.egg/formencode/declarative.py", line 128, in __init__
    % name)
TypeError: keyword parameter 'validatorArgs' was given by position and name
```

The message is not so true, since `validatorArgs` was actually only given by name, anyway.

items.title: Wrong import statement breaks others import.
items.body:
I'm new to python so I could have deduced it wrong.

There is an error in the Email validator.

I receive the following error:

idna_domain = [idna.ToASCII(p) for p in domain.split('.')]
NameError: global name 'idna' is not defined

My error detection and solution:

In the file validators.py at line 16:
"from encodings import idna" does not reach because two lines above: "import dns.resolver" and "import dns.exception" raises an exception because I really don't have installed "dnspython" and consequently the line 16 does not import as needed.

Solution?
Move the statement at line 16 to line 12, aka outside try...catch block.
Or... at live 1340 where the error occur, put some if checks?

I don't want to install it since it's features is optional and don't needed.

items.title: Use decorator syntax
items.body: Since version 1.3 requires Py 2.6, it should make use of decorator syntax internally (e.g. for declaring static methods or properties). This makes the code better readable.

items.title: Add tests for subclassing FancyValidator and CompoundValidator
items.body:
The `FancyValidator` class supports subclassing by overriding the methods `_from_python`, `_to_python`, `validate_python` and `validate_other` and the `CompoundValidator` class can be extended by overriding the `attempt_convert` method.

We need some unittests which check that subclassing by overriding these methods works as advertized. This is particlularly important since in #18 we want to rename the methods which are supposed to be overriden, but not to be used externally, so that they all start with an underscore. If we want backwards compatibilty, we must assure that overriding works with the old and the new names. When using the old names, we should get deprecation warnings.

items.title: validators.OneOf w/ testValueList=True not functional
items.body:
Changes in 1.2.5 appear to have made the testValueList non-functional when a validator.OneOf field is in a Schema:

``` python
class foo(Schema):
    bar = validators.OneOf((1,2,3), testValueList=True)

foo.to_python({'bar':(1,2,3)})
```

Result: `Invalid: bar: Please provide only one value`

If I add `accept_iterator=True` to validators.OneOf, the result is `{'bar': (1, 2, 3)}`

items.title: Release 1.2.5
items.body: The current version on PyPi doesn't even support HTML 5 input types. Would it be possible to release Formencode 1.2.5?

items.title: Consider renaming FancyValidator methods
items.body:
FormEncode's FancyValidators add four internal methods that can be overridden to modify the behavior of the external methods `to_pyton()` and `from_python()`. However, two of these internal methods start with an underscore and two do not which is confusing (see issue #17). I have already tried to improve the documentation and explain more clearly what these methods are used for, but we may want to also change the method names in a later release to make them more self-explanatory. Either all or none of the internal methods should have a leading underscore. I think, since they are actually private methods, they should have a leading underscore according to PEP8. Also, the `to_python()` and `_to_python()` methods should have more different names, since they do different things. The former also validates, while the latter only converts. So I suggest the following possible naming schemes for the internal methods which are all better than the current names:

```
current name     suggestion 1      suggestion 2         suggestion 3

_to_python       _to_python        convert_to_python    _convert_to_python
_from_python     _from_python      convert_from_python  _convert_from_python
validate_python  _validate_python  validate_python      _validate_python
validate_other   _validate_other   validate_other       _validate_other
```

I tend to suggestion 3, but we need to decide whether the added clarity is really worth the compatibility breach and in which version this should happen.

items.title: Clarify behavior of validators
items.body:
FormEncode's FancyValidators come with the two methods `to_python()` and `validate_python()` that can both throw validation errors. Unfortunately, the documentation does not really explain what those two methods validate. Take for example the Int validator that can take a min and a max parameter, too. Obviously, the validation whether an input value is an integer can only be checked in `to_python()`, since `validate_python()` already expects an integer. However, the validation whether the value falls into the given min/max range could happen in either `to_python()` or in `validate_python()` or in both. How is a FancyValidator supposed to behave in this case? Should everything be validated at the "latest possible level only" or "on all possible levels"? Do I always  need to call `validate_python()` after `to_python()` to make sure a value is really valid? Or does it suffice to call `to_python()`? Can we agree on something here and add it to the documention? Another ambiguity arises when you combine a min/max range of an Int or String with a not_empty parameter. Which should take precedence? Should an empty string pass or not? This should be documented as well.

One of the reasons I want this to be clarified is that ToscaWidgets 2 comes with a validator API that is supposed to mimic FormEncode, but in reality the validator methods behave differently (see toscawidgets/tw2.core#65). It is important that we define a "proper" behavior.

items.title: Schema with UnicodeString item behaves unclearly
items.body:
Here's an example.

``` python
# =====================
from formencode import Schema, Invalid
from formencode.validators import UnicodeString, Int
from webob import Request

class StrictSchema(Schema):
    allow_extra_fields = False

class IntegerTestSchema(StrictSchema):
    testfield = Int(not_empty=True)

class StringTestSchema(StrictSchema):
    testfield = UnicodeString(not_empty=True)

# Testing.
# =====================
req = Request.blank('/?testfield=111')
print IntegerTestSchema.to_python(req.params)

# This raises an exception
req = Request.blank('/?testfield=111&testfield=222')
try:
    IntegerTestSchema.to_python(req.params)
except Invalid as e:
    print "Caught Exception: {0}".format(e)

req = Request.blank('/?testfield=aaa')
print StringTestSchema.to_python(req.params)

# This will be passed successfully (!)
# The output will be {'testfield': u"[u'aaa', u'bbb']"}
req = Request.blank('/?testfield=aaa&testfield=bbb')
print StringTestSchema.to_python(req.params)

# ========================
```

Please note we do not use formencode.ForEach() or formencode.Set()
here. I think this is very unclear behaviour.

This behavior happens because mixed is used here - https://github.com/formencode/formencode/blob/0a979677cce85e05d2c190708c599df382882bb5/formencode/api.py#L410
For example, if we'd have an unified behaviour for all single-value validators (Int, UnicodeString, Bool etc.) we could get "[u'John', u'Mike']" result only for "/?username=[u'John', u'Mike']" request. But now, we can get the same result by the two different requests - by "/?username=[u'John', u'Mike']" and by "/? username=John&username=Mike". This shouldn't be allowed.

Original discussion has been started here - http://groups.google.com/group/pylons-discuss/browse_thread/thread/ccbfeac4c12d3a9b

Original Report: https://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=3179722&group_id=91231&atid=596416

items.title: htmlfill doesnt respect prefix_error=False for file elements
items.body:
normally the part for file element in input handle function looks like this:

``` python
elif t == 'file':
pass # don't skip next
```

i changed it to this:

``` python
elif t == 'file':
self.write_tag('input', attrs, startend)
self.skip_next = True
self.add_key(name)
```

now when i pass prefix_error=False, then error is printed after actual element, original version of code always gets the error rendered in front of file element

Original Report: https://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=3018732&group_id=91231&atid=596416

items.title: DNS lookup error when e-mail address is unicode
items.body:
I'm using Python 2.4, but it happens with python 2.5 also. pydns is 2.3.3, formencode is version 1.2.2.

Reproducing test case:

``` python
>>> import formencode.validators
>>> e = formencode.validators.Email(resolve_domain=True)
>>> e.to_python(u'foo@example.com')
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
File "/home/ecardg5/python/lib/python2.5/site-packages/FormEncode-1.2.1-py2.5.egg/formencode/api.py", line 416, in to_python
vp(value, state)
File "/home/ecardg5/python/lib/python2.5/site-packages/FormEncode-1.2.1-py2.5.egg/formencode/validators.py", line 1364, in validate_python
a=DNS.DnsRequest(domain, qtype='mx').req().answers
File "build/bdist.linux-i686/egg/DNS/Base.py", line 202, in req
File "build/bdist.linux-i686/egg/DNS/Lib.py", line 461, in addQuestion
File "build/bdist.linux-i686/egg/DNS/Lib.py", line 128, in addname
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x92 in position 1: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I note that 2126902 was already filed, but closed as wfm.

Original Report: https://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=2788514&group_id=91231&atid=596416

items.title: htmlfill.render() does not clear <input type="text"> fields
items.body:
When the defaults dict passed to htmlfill.render() is empty, and force_defaults=True, htmlfill clears <textarea> fields (as well as checkboxes, radio buttons, and select fields), but leaves the value of an <input type="text"> alone. This is inconsistent and, IMHO, buggy. The same applies to "hidden" and "password" fields.

I'm attaching a failing test.

Original Report: https://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=2616831&group_id=91231&atid=596416

items.title: FillingParser.handle_option selects any option with value=""
items.body:
In FormEncode version 1.2 FillingParser.handle_option has a check on lines 463-464 of htmlfill.py, that if it passes, ads 'selected="selected"' to the option element. The nature of the check means that any option with an attribute of 'value=""' will pass and become selected. Not only is this not the desired behavior (only those options which have been specified in form defaults should be selected), but it also means that bizarre circumstances occur, such as having an option that has the attribute 'disabled="disabled"' still get selected, which most browsers are incapable of doing through normal user interactions.

Originally report: https://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=2393660&group_id=91231&atid=596416
